newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Mobil Australia tanker dispute resolved.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Mobil Australia tanker dispute resolved.

text.p: Oil refiners in Australia have agreed to extend their charter of a 96,000-tonne crude tanker, ending a week-long dispute at Mobil Oil Australia's Altona refinery here, union and Mobil sources said on Monday.

The deal to charter the Canopus for another year was reached on Friday night and ended a strike aboard the tanker, which had been prevented by its crew from unloading at Mobil's 108,000 barrels-per-day refinery since late October 10, they said.
The ship, stranded with about 30,000 tonnes of griffin crude when the crew downed tools, completed unloading and sailed on Saturday for a Singapore dry dock, shipping sources said.

The consortium of refiners chartering the tanker -- Mobil, British Petroleum Co Plc and Ampol Petroleum Pty Ltd -- had planned to stop using the Australian-crewed ship this month, but agreed to extend the charter after talks with the MUA.
"That vessel will continue in its trade for 12 months to give the parties an opportunity to develop structural efficiencies through enterprise bargaining," MUA official Mick Doleman said on Monday.
"We are more than happy to work to improve our competitive position in a rational way," he told Reuters.

The dispute aboard the Canopus did not affect production or supply to the Altona refinery, Mobil spokeswoman Samantha Potts said, confirming the ship had been carrying a total of 80,000 tonnes of crude, not 80,000 litres as previously cited by Mobil.
But the issue has highlighted a move by oil majors in Australia to increasingly use foreign-crewed tankers for their marine crude supplies, the union and Mobil representatives said.
Mobil had said before last Friday's agreement that the Canopus consortium no longer suited the company and that it wanted to charter more efficient foreign-crewed vessels instead.
The Canopus and its sister tanker the Era, which is also chartered by oil refiners in Australia, have both been sold recently by Howard Smith Ltd for US$52.5 million.

The Canopus' new owner, Greek firm Liquimar, has yet to agree to a new charter but the agreement obliges the refiners to charter another Australian-crewed tanker if the Canopus is no longer available, the MUA and the shipping sources said.
Renegotiation for Era's charter is due early next year. The Era is chartered by BP, Mobil, Ampol and Royal Dutch/Shell.
